title: AI in design
content:
I, for one, don't mind design tools experimenting with AI features.

Much of what we're doing is just going through the motions until we reach the stage where the real work begins. If a tool can help me design an MVP of a form in 3 seconds that would have otherwise required 1,200 clicks, I'm greeting it with open arms.

My valuable skill is not drawing boxes in slightly different iterations but thinking about complex products that require a bird's-eye view and a vision. It will take some time until AI gets us there.

title: mathematics and beauty
content:
There's something profoundly beautiful about mathematical expressions. The Pythagorean theorem $a^2 + b^2 = c^2$ is elegant in its simplicity yet powerful in its applications.

Einstein's field equations of general relativity are another example of mathematical beauty:

$$G_{\mu\nu} = \frac{8\pi G}{c^4}T_{\mu\nu}$$

This compact equation describes how matter and energy curve spacetime. The left side represents the curvature of spacetime, while the right side represents the energy and momentum of matter.

Even the simple quadratic formula has its own elegance:

$$x = \frac{-b \pm \sqrt{b^2 - 4ac}}{2a}$$

Mathematics is the language of the universe, and these equations are its poetry.

title: running ideas
content:
The best ideas come to me when I'm running. There's something about the rhythm of movement and the absence of screens that lets my mind wander productively.

Today's run yielded three potential solutions to a problem I've been stuck on for weeks. Going to prototype them tomorrow and see which one works best.

Maybe we should rename 'running' to 'thinking in motion'.

title: how do you grow?
content:
Growth happens in the spaces between comfort and panic.

Too comfortable? You're not learning anything new.

Too panicked? Your brain can't process effectively.

The sweet spot is that stretch zone where you feel challenged but not overwhelmed. I try to spend at least an hour there every day.

title: keeping it simple
content:
Complexity is easy. Simplicity is hard.

Anyone can add features until the product does everything poorly. The real challenge is removing elements until you have something that does a few things exceptionally well.

My design mantra for this year: If in doubt, take it out.

title: drink some hot cocoa
content:
Sometimes the most productive thing you can do is make yourself a cup of hot cocoa and stare out the window for 15 minutes.

Our brains need downtime to process, connect, and create. Constant input without reflection leads to mental congestion.

The hot cocoa is optional, but highly recommended.

title: walk to ikea
content:
Walked to IKEA today instead of driving. It's only 3 miles away, but it feels like a pilgrimage when you're on foot.

The journey through the city revealed so many details I miss when driving: a new coffee shop, an interesting piece of street art, a tiny park I never knew existed.

Bought a single plant and carried it home like a trophy. Somehow more satisfying than a car full of furniture.

title: a parasite
content:
Finally watched Parasite. A masterclass in tension, visual storytelling, and social commentary without being preachy.

The way it shifts between comedy, thriller, and tragedy so seamlessly is remarkable. Every frame feels intentional.

It's rare to find a film that's both accessible and layered with meaning. Will be thinking about this one for weeks.
